Then the recession hit, along with a global

Long story, but it hit me hard. For two years,

had to go and live with their Dad, as I couldn't

I couldn’t give my expertise in online marketing

turnover business, ClicksAndLeads.com, a boutique

I made my mind up to launch that business

253.text:
(would have been 3 but a friend was sick and

259.text:
So what made the difference? What was it that

275.text:
Because the first time I read “The Science
Of Getting Rich”, back in 2003 or 2004,

280.text:
along with the more famous book that followed
it “Think And Grow Rich” by Napoleon Hill,

286.text:
Those books laid it all out for me – the
most important information in the whole world

290.text:
was there for me to know - but I just couldn’t
absorb the information in the way it was presented.

296.text:
The book was totally male orientated, written
in archaic language, loads of references to

301.text:
religion and God (who, being a confirmed agnostic
then, I just didn’t believe in) and somehow

306.text:
all those things combined to make sure I just
didn't’ get it.

310.text:
At the time I was looking for surefire tactics
to implement and not esoteric, waffly thoughts

315.text: from some old school geezer back in the day!

319.text:
The only reason I re-read the book was because
my podcast co-host Judith Morgan and I had

325.text:
just interviewed Jacqueline Rogers, founder

329.text:
Laptop Lifestyle” virtual summit. Judith

336.text:
Jacqueline had been a big hit on the Summit

341.text:
We have a section on the podcast called “Project

that, as it was out of copyright, she was

349.text:
for women and I was struck by what a great

352.text:
I went off and found a copy online, printed

356.text:
did I found that (religious references notwithstanding)
I agreed with every single word! It all made

362.text:
total sense based on what I had been through

367.text: How A Science Show On The BBC Changed My Thinking

371.text:
A while ago, I read a book called “Synchronicity:
The Inner Path Of Leadership” by Joseph

376.text:
From Amazon: Synchronicity is an inspirational
guide to developing the most essential leadership

381.text:
capacity for our time: the ability to collectively
shape our future. By telling the story of

387.text:
his remarkable journey toward an understanding
of the deep issues of leadership, Joseph Jaworski

392.text:
explains the fundamental shifts of mind that
will enable leaders to listen to realities

396.text:
that want to emerge in this world and acquire
the courage to manifest them.

400.text:
The reason I loved it particularly, was it
told Joseph’s own “Hero’s Journey”

404.text:
story of having a nervous breakdown, then
travelling the world in search of a new life,

410.text:
but some co-incidences lead him to study the
phenomenon of Synchronicity, talking to many

415.text:
physicists along the way, and how that can
be partially, if not completely be explained

422.text:
More recently, I watched the short series
on British TV called “The Forces Of Nature”

429.text:
Brian Edward Cox, OBE FRS is an English physicist,
and Advanced Fellow of particle physics in

435.text:
the School of Physics and Astronomy at the
University of Manchester. Perhaps he was one

440.text:
of the people Joseph Jaworski talked to when
writing his book?

444.text:
Cox has been described as the natural successor
for leading the BBC's scientific programming

448.text:
by both David Attenborough and the late Patrick
Moore and I have to agree – he makes the

453.text:
most complicated concepts almost completely
understandable.

457.text:
(Amusingly, before his academic career, Cox
was a keyboard player for the band D:Ream,

462.text:
best known for their hit “Things Will Only
Get Better” a positive upbeat song if ever

467.text:
From the description of the series on the
BBC website:

470.text:
“Professor Brian Cox combines some of the
most spectacular sights on Earth with our

474.text:
deepest understanding of the universe to reveal
how the planet’s beauty is created by just

482.text:
The science is amazing, the photography / filming
is amazing, the music is amazing and he blew

487.text:
my mind with some of the statements he made,
one while walking through an English ancient

494.text:
"Life is just the temporary home of the immortal
elements that build up the Universe"

501.text:
He went on to explain the Time / Space continuum,
which he explained by pointing out that we

505.text:
are hurtling through space at around 650 miles
an hour, even though when we stand on the

511.text:
surface of the planet it doesn’t feel like
we are moving at all.

515.text:
He talked about how that planet was also moving
around the Sun as well as rotating on it’s

519.text:
axis and somehow, all that meant that everything
that happens to us – good or bad - is happening

525.text:
still out there in the Universe somewhere,
every moment still exists and every moment

532.text:
This could even mean that there are an infinite
number of Universes (the “Many Worlds”

537.text: theory) existing next to each other.

541.text:
Later in the same show he said “We are of
the Earth, constructed from a ready supply

545.text: of chemical elements, forged in the Stars”

548.text:
Nowadays I’m a confirmed atheist, preferring
the total liberation that comes when you know,

553.text:
deep in your heart, that nothing outside you
has any dominion over what happens to you,

558.text:
that there is no ethereal deity who could
come and save you but chooses not to, that

562.text:
whatever happens for good or ill, it’s all
down to you as to how you react to it.

567.text:
I’ve just lost my best friend (and sometime
life partner) Steve Watson, who died very

572.text:
suddenly back in March 2016, just a few months
ago as I write this. I’m over the worst

577.text:
of the grieving, the agonising minute by minute
pain that you feel in the early days, the

581.text:
many unanswerable questions are subsiding
and I just get very, very sad sometimes at

588.text:
what we’ll miss out on for the rest of the
time we would have had together.

591.text:
I found Prof. Cox’s words very moving and
somewhat consoling in my loss. The thought

597.text:
that every wonderful moment we had (and all
the fights!) are still happening out there

601.text: somewhere, made it all feel a bit less final.

604.text:
However, the bigger concept for the purposes
of explaining one of the reasons why I wanted

609.text:
to rewrite this book for you, was the concept
that we were all made of the same stuff, not

614.text:
just us humans, but the acorn he was holding,
the fallen tree he was sitting on, the sofa

619.text:
I was sitting on, the TV I was watching him
on…

623.text:
We are all made from about 90 chemical elements,
forged in the stars, by some miracle of evolution

629.text:
and that we were on earth for a tiny, tiny
amount of time…well, when I read “The

634.text:
Science Of Getting Rich” again, it all just
clicked into place.

637.text:
Remember, Prof Cox said "Life is just the
temporary home of the immortal elements that

645.text:
Life itself, that ephemeral thing, that can’t
be bottled or hung onto, but can be seen and

650.text:
be seen to leave, that’s the miracle I can
get my arms around.

656.text:
If you change the words Wallace used, it all
makes sense in the 21st Century too.

662.text:
If you change the word God into Universal
Energy, if you change the words Formless Stuff

666.text:
into Life, short for those 90 chemical elements,
the Atoms (positive) and Photons (negative)

672.text:
that make up everything, and if you change
the words Increasing into Abundance, it all

678.text:
suddenly makes sense to a 54 year old, feminist,
atheist, digital marketer.

683.text: Why “The Science Of Getting Rich Online”?

686.text:

691.text:

one.

a compelling and value driven offer in front

698.text: of as large a number of people as possible.
